channel.title: Nature
channel.description: Nature is the foremost international weekly scientific journal in the world and is the flagship journal for Nature Portfolio. It publishes the finest peer-reviewed research in all fields of science and technology on the basis of its originality, importance, interdisciplinary interest, timeliness, accessibility, elegance and surprising conclusions. Nature publishes landmark papers, award winning news, leading comment and expert opinion on important, topical scientific news and events that enable readers to share the latest discoveries in science and evolve the discussion amongst the global scientific community.
channel.dc:rights: © 2023 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.
channel.prism:copyright: © 2023 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.

item.title: Postdoc unions can help secure a brighter future
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01007-y

Postdoc unions can help secure a brighter future
item.dc:title: Postdoc unions can help secure a brighter future
item.dc:creator: Neal Sweeney

item.title: eLife: community support for a new publishing model
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01005-0

eLife: community support for a new publishing model
item.dc:title: eLife: community support for a new publishing model
item.dc:creator: Lara Urban
Devang Mehta

item.title: A boost for south–south collaboration
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01003-2

A boost for south–south collaboration
item.dc:title: A boost for south–south collaboration
item.dc:creator: Franco M. Cabrerizo

item.title: NIH funding: hone efforts to tackle structural racism
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01004-1

NIH funding: hone efforts to tackle structural racism
item.dc:title: NIH funding: hone efforts to tackle structural racism
item.dc:creator: Adesuwa Akhetuamhen
Eseosa T. Ighodaro
Kortney F. James
Nora Franco
Renee Hsia

item.title: University ethics boards are not ready for Indigenous scholars
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-00974-6

Ethics review processes routinely impede Indigenous academics’ research with Indigenous communities.
item.dc:title: University ethics boards are not ready for Indigenous scholars
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Grenz

item.title: Three ways to solve the plastics pollution crisis
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-00975-5

Researchers are studying how more-sophisticated policies, smarter recycling and new materials could stem the tide of waste.
item.dc:title: Three ways to solve the plastics pollution crisis
item.dc:creator: Diana Kwon

item.title: I analyse ‘extremophile’ microbes to understand life’s origins
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-00985-3

Microbiologist Gaël Erauso studies microorganisms from the deep ocean to learn how they evolved from prebiotic organic molecules billions of years ago.
item.dc:title: I analyse ‘extremophile’ microbes to understand life’s origins
item.dc:creator: Hannah Docter-Loeb

item.title: How Stephen Hawking flip-flopped on whether the Universe has a beginning
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-00977-3

The question of what the Big Bang really represented still bamboozles cosmologists — and Hawking provided more than one answer.
item.dc:title: How Stephen Hawking flip-flopped on whether the Universe has a beginning
item.dc:creator: Robert P. Crease

item.title: Understanding the difference between the mind and the brain
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 07 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01017-w

Neuroscientist Chantel Prat is keen to understand why, despite a growing awareness of diversity and its importance, we still sometimes struggle to accept different perspectives.
item.dc:title: Understanding the difference between the mind and the brain
item.dc:creator: Dom Byrne

item.title: The good side of science: why I tweeted 31 reasons to love your career
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 07 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01027-8

Jeffrey Rathmell took to Twitter after encountering negativity on social media about research careers. He was surprised by the experience, and the overwhelmingly positive response.
item.dc:title: The good side of science: why I tweeted 31 reasons to love your career
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Rathmell

item.title: Death threats, trolling and sexist abuse: climate scientists report online attacks
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01018-9

Survey highlights experiences of dozens of climate researchers who have endured online harassment related to their work.
item.dc:title: Death threats, trolling and sexist abuse: climate scientists report online attacks
item.dc:creator: Myriam Vidal Valero

item.title: Crazy ants’ strange genomes are a biological first
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01002-3

Males of the notorious yellow crazy ant carry a mixture of genomes, a phenomenon unseen in other animals.
item.dc:title: Crazy ants’ strange genomes are a biological first
item.dc:creator: Ewen Callaway

item.title: Researchers back African Union to join G20 group of largest economic powers
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01014-z

Including African Union in the G20 is a matter of ethics and fairness, researchers say.
item.dc:title: Researchers back African Union to join G20 group of largest economic powers
item.dc:creator: T.V. Padma

item.title: Global scholars decry funding ban on influential Indian research centre
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-00995-1

International dismay after New Delhi-based Centre for Policy Research funding suspended.
item.dc:title: Global scholars decry funding ban on influential Indian research centre
item.dc:creator: Dyani Lewis

item.title: Stem-cell-derived ‘embryos’ implanted in monkeys
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-00996-0

An embryo-like ball of cells offers a way to study pregnancy and its complications without the typical ethical dilemmas.
item.dc:title: Stem-cell-derived ‘embryos’ implanted in monkeys
item.dc:creator: Gemma Conroy

item.title: Sounds of science: how music at work can fine-tune your research
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-00984-4

Researchers describe how listening to music at work can boost (or hamper) productivity, and share the tunes that keep them focused.
item.dc:title: Sounds of science: how music at work can fine-tune your research
item.dc:creator: Nikki Forrester

item.title: How to have two careers, and be happy with both
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-00991-5

Touring the world as a bass player in a heavy-metal band alongside being a full-time physicist requires career compromises, says Alessandro Sala.
item.dc:title: How to have two careers, and be happy with both
item.dc:creator: Alessandro Sala

item.title: Searching the web for science: how small mistakes create big problems
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01011-2

Typos, acronyms and authors’ names all present issues when trawling the literature. Can next-generation search engines do better?
item.dc:title: Searching the web for science: how small mistakes create big problems
item.dc:creator: Jack Leeming

item.title: How to make lithium extraction cleaner, faster and cheaper — in six steps
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-00978-2

Demand for lithium for batteries and other green technologies is exploding. The industry must develop sustainable methods to remove and process the element from ores and brines to avoid environmental damage.
item.dc:title: How to make lithium extraction cleaner, faster and cheaper — in six steps
item.dc:creator: Andrew Z. Haddad
Lukas Hackl
Bilen Akuzum
Garrett Pohlman
Jean-François Magnan
Robert Kostecki

item.title: Author Correction: Basin-scale reconstruction of euxinia and Late Devonian mass extinctions
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 April 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-05999-5

Author Correction: Basin-scale reconstruction of euxinia and Late Devonian mass extinctions
item.dc:title: Author Correction: Basin-scale reconstruction of euxinia and Late Devonian mass extinctions

item.content:encoded:

Surveillance of SARS-CoV-2 at the Huanan Seafood Market
item.dc:title: Surveillance of SARS-CoV-2 at the Huanan Seafood Market

item.title: Giant black-hole pair from the early Universe gives clues to how galaxies form
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01006-z

Researchers see most distant pair of supermassive black holes yet observed, and assessing an AI's ability to interpret heart images.
item.dc:title: Giant black-hole pair from the early Universe gives clues to how galaxies form
item.dc:creator: Nick Petrić Howe
Shamini Bundell

item.title: Finery in an Anglo-Saxon grave came from African ivory
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-00904-6

An ornament buried with an elite woman from the fifth or sixth century ad was probably made in an East African workshop.
item.dc:title: Finery in an Anglo-Saxon grave came from African ivory

item.title: Fierce fires lessen a forest’s appetite for carbon
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-00907-3

Extreme blazes mean that woods in California take longer to return to their pre-fire rate of carbon uptake.
item.dc:title: Fierce fires lessen a forest’s appetite for carbon

item.title: A close quasar pair in a disk–disk galaxy merger at z = 2.17
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 April 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-05766-6

The authors report multiwavelength observations of SDSS J0749 + 2255, hosted by massive compact disk-dominated galaxies, as a kpc-scale, dual-quasar system hosted by a galaxy merger at cosmic noon.
item.dc:title: A close quasar pair in a disk–disk galaxy merger at z = 2.17
item.dc:creator: Yu-Ching Chen
Xin Liu
Adi Foord
Yue Shen
Masamune Oguri
Nianyi Chen
Tiziana Di Matteo
Miguel Holgado
Hsiang-Chih Hwang
Nadia Zakamska

item.title: mRNA recognition and packaging by the human transcription–export complex
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 April 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-05904-0

Cryo-electron microscopy and tomography structures of reconstituted and endogenous human mRNA ribonucleoprotein complexes bound to the transcription–export complex reveal how mRNAs are packaged and recognized for nuclear export.
item.dc:title: mRNA recognition and packaging by the human transcription–export complex
item.dc:creator: Belén Pacheco-Fiallos
Matthias K. Vorländer
Daria Riabov-Bassat
Laura Fin
Francis J. O’Reilly
Farja I. Ayala
Ulla Schellhaas
Juri Rappsilber
Clemens Plaschka

item.title: Rapid, buoyancy-driven ice-sheet retreat of hundreds of metres per day
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 April 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-05876-1

Analysis of more than 7,600 corrugation ridges on the Norwegian continental shelf shows that rapid grounding-line retreat of several hundred metres per day occurred across low-gradient ice-sheet beds during the last deglaciation.
item.dc:title: Rapid, buoyancy-driven ice-sheet retreat of hundreds of metres per day
item.dc:creator: Christine L. Batchelor
Frazer D. W. Christie
Dag Ottesen
Aleksandr Montelli
Jeffrey Evans
Evelyn K. Dowdeswell
Lilja R. Bjarnadóttir
Julian A. Dowdeswell

item.title: De novo design of modular peptide-binding proteins by superhelical matching
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 April 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-05909-9

A computational approach is used to design modular proteins that bind to synthetic peptides and disordered regions of human proteins with high affinity and specificity.
item.dc:title: De novo design of modular peptide-binding proteins by superhelical matching
item.dc:creator: Kejia Wu
Hua Bai

item.title: Deforming lanthanum trihydride for superionic conduction
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 April 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-05815-0

By creating nanosized grains and defects in lanthanum trihydride, its electronic conductivity can be suppressed, transforming it into a superionic conductor at −40 °C with a record high H− conductivity.
item.dc:title: Deforming lanthanum trihydride for superionic conduction
item.dc:creator: Weijin Zhang
Jirong Cui

item.title: Blinded, randomized trial of sonographer versus AI cardiac function assessment
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 April 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-05947-3

The impact of artificial intelligence in cardiac function assessment is evaluated by a blinded, randomized non-inferiority trial of artificial intelligence versus sonographer initial assessment of the left ventricular ejection fraction.
item.dc:title: Blinded, randomized trial of sonographer versus AI cardiac function assessment
item.dc:creator: Bryan He

item.title: Two-dimensional ferroelectricity in a single-element bismuth monolayer
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 April 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-05848-5

A single-element ferroelectric state is observed in a black phosphorus-like bismuth layer, in which the ordered charge transfer and the regular atom distortion between sublattices happen simultaneously and ferroelectric switching is further visualized experimentally.
item.dc:title: Two-dimensional ferroelectricity in a single-element bismuth monolayer
item.dc:creator: Jian Gou
Hua Bai
Xuanlin Zhang
Yu Li Huang
Sisheng Duan
A. Ariando

Lan Chen

Andrew Thye Shen Wee

item.title: Lunar eclipses illuminate timing and climate impact of medieval volcanism
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 April 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-05751-z

Analysis of contemporary reports of total lunar eclipses, combined with aerosol model simulations and tree-ring-based climate proxies, allowed greater precision in dating of the occurrence of stratospheric volcanic eruptions during the High Medieval Period.
item.dc:title: Lunar eclipses illuminate timing and climate impact of medieval volcanism
item.dc:creator: Sébastien Guillet
Christophe Corona

Franck Lavigne

Nobuko Horikawa
Markus Stoffel

item.title: Lung adenocarcinoma promotion by air pollutants
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 April 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-05874-3

Combination of epidemiology, preclinical models and ultradeep DNA profiling of clinical cohorts unpicks the inflammatory mechanism by which air pollution promotes lung cancer
item.dc:title: Lung adenocarcinoma promotion by air pollutants

item.title: Tracking chromatin state changes using nanoscale photo-proximity labelling
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 April 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-05914-y

A proximity labelling-based approach for mapping nuclear protein–protein interactions is described that could advance epigenetic drug discovery.
item.dc:title: Tracking chromatin state changes using nanoscale photo-proximity labelling
item.dc:creator: Ciaran P. Seath
Antony J. Burton
Xuemeng Sun
Gihoon Lee
Ralph E. Kleiner
David W. C. MacMillan
Tom W. Muir

item.title: The NK cell receptor NKp46 recognizes ecto-calreticulin on ER-stressed cells
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 April 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-05912-0

NKp46 recognizes externalized calreticulin, which translocates from the ER to the cell membrane during ER stress, indicating a danger-associated molecular pattern that eliminates ER-stressed cells.
item.dc:title: The NK cell receptor NKp46 recognizes ecto-calreticulin on ER-stressed cells
item.dc:creator: Sumit Sen Santara

item.title: Establishment and function of chromatin organization at replication origins
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 April 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-05926-8

Genome-scale in vitro reconstitution of DNA replication through chromatin establishes a crucial role for the origin recognition complex in organizing nucleosome arrays that are crucial for the initiation of replication.
item.dc:title: Establishment and function of chromatin organization at replication origins
item.dc:creator: Erika Chacin
Karl-Uwe Reusswig
Jessica Furtmeier
Priyanka Bansal

item.title: Cryo-EM structure of the transposon-associated TnpB enzyme
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 April 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-05933-9

Cryo-electron microscopy analysis of the Deinococcus radiodurans ISDra2 TnpB in complex with its cognate ωRNA and target DNA provides insights into the mechanism of TnpB function and the evolution of CRISPR–Cas12 effectors.
item.dc:title: Cryo-EM structure of the transposon-associated TnpB enzyme
item.dc:creator: Ryoya Nakagawa

item.title: Net greenhouse gas balance of fibre wood plantation on peat in Indonesia
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 April 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-05860-9

Measurements of the net ecosystem exchanges of CO2, CH4 and soil N2O from Acacia plantation, degraded forest and intact forest enable presentation of the peatland wood plantation rotation greenhouse gas flux balance.
item.dc:title: Net greenhouse gas balance of fibre wood plantation on peat in Indonesia
item.dc:creator: Chandra S. Deshmukh

item.title: mRNA decoding in human is kinetically and structurally distinct from bacteria
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 April 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-05908-w

The reaction coordinate of aminoacyl-tRNA movement is altered on the human ribosome and the process is an order of magnitude slower compared with bacteria due to eukaryote-specific structural elements in the human ribosome and in the elongation factor eEF1A.
item.dc:title: mRNA decoding in human is kinetically and structurally distinct from bacteria
item.dc:creator: Mikael Holm
S. Kundhavai Natchiar
Emily J. Rundlet
Alexander G. Myasnikov
Zoe L. Watson
Roger B. Altman
Hao-Yuan Wang
Jack Taunton
Scott C. Blanchard

item.title: Plastic and stimulus-specific coding of salient events in the central amygdala
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 April 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-05910-2

Neurons in the central amygdala contribute to the reward prediction error responses of dopamine neurons to facilitate reward learning, but are not involved in aversive learning.
item.dc:title: Plastic and stimulus-specific coding of salient events in the central amygdala
item.dc:creator: Tao Yang
Kai Yu
Xian Zhang
Xiong Xiao
Xiaoke Chen
Yu Fu
Bo Li

item.title: A viral biomolecular condensate coordinates assembly of progeny particles
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 April 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-05887-y

Phase separation of the human adenovirus 52-kDa protein has an essential role in the formation of biomolecular condensates, regulating the coordinated assembly of viral progeny particles.
item.dc:title: A viral biomolecular condensate coordinates assembly of progeny particles
item.dc:creator: Matthew Charman
Nicholas Grams
Namrata Kumar
Edwin Halko
Joseph M. Dybas
Amber Abbott
Krystal K. Lum
Daniel Blumenthal
Elene Tsopurashvili
Matthew D. Weitzman

item.title: Self-powered perovskite photon-counting detectors
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 April 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-05847-6

Suppression of shallow traps responsible for dark count rates in polycrystalline methylammonium lead triiodide using diphenyl sulfide enables the production of metal-halide perovskite photon-counting detectors that allow sensitive detection of γ-ray spectra.
item.dc:title: Self-powered perovskite photon-counting detectors
item.dc:creator: Ying Zhou
Chengbin Fei
Md Aslam Uddin
Liang Zhao
Zhenyi Ni
Jinsong Huang

item.title: A LaCl<sub>3</sub>-based lithium superionic conductor compatible with lithium metal
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 April 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-05899-8

A LaCl3-based lithium superionic conductor is developed that has excellent interfacial compatibility with lithium metal electrodes, with its optimized Li0.388Ta0.238La0.475Cl3 electrolyte exhibiting good Li+ conductivity and low activation energy.
item.dc:title: A LaCl<sub>3</sub>-based lithium superionic conductor compatible with lithium metal
item.dc:creator: Yi-Chen Yin

item.title: Selective methane oxidation by molecular iron catalysts in aqueous medium
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 April 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-05821-2

Methane can be oxidized to methanol using N-heterocyclic carbene-ligated FeII complexes, in which the hydrophobic cavity captures the methane substrate from an aqueous solution and releases the hydrophilic methanol product back into the solution.
item.dc:title: Selective methane oxidation by molecular iron catalysts in aqueous medium
item.dc:creator: Hiroto Fujisaki
Tomoya Ishizuka
Hiroaki Kotani
Yoshihito Shiota
Kazunari Yoshizawa
Takahiko Kojima

item.title: Large-scale mapping and mutagenesis of human transcriptional effector domains
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 April 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-05906-y

A high throughput recruitment assay testing the transcriptional activity of more than 100,000 protein fragments tiling across most human chromatin regulators and transcription factors maps the locations and strengths of activation, repression and bifunctional domains, and identifies the sequences necessary for these functions.
item.dc:title: Large-scale mapping and mutagenesis of human transcriptional effector domains
item.dc:creator: Nicole DelRosso

Peter Suzuki
Cecelia Andrews
Aradhana
Adi Mukund

Lacramioara Bintu

item.title: TnpB structure reveals minimal functional core of Cas12 nuclease family
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 April 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-05826-x

Cryo-EM structures of D. radiodurans TnpB–reRNA complex in DNA-bound and -free forms reveal the basic architecture of TnpB nuclease and the molecular mechanism for DNA target recognition and cleavage supported by biochemical experiments.
item.dc:title: TnpB structure reveals minimal functional core of Cas12 nuclease family
item.dc:creator: Giedrius Sasnauskas
Giedre Tamulaitiene
Gytis Druteika
Arturo Carabias

Darius Kazlauskas
Česlovas Venclovas

Tautvydas Karvelis
Virginijus Siksnys

item.title: The WHO at 75: what doesn’t kill you makes you stronger
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-00952-y

The World Health Organization is emerging from the peak of the pandemic bruised. Its member states must get back to prioritizing universal health care.
item.dc:title: The WHO at 75: what doesn’t kill you makes you stronger

item.title: Air pollution’s role in the promotion of lung cancer
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-00929-x

Air pollution is associated with the development of lung cancer. Analysis of clinical samples and mouse cancer models suggests that inflammation and a tumour-promotion process induced by polluted air are the major culprits.
item.dc:title: Air pollution’s role in the promotion of lung cancer
item.dc:creator: Allan Balmain

item.title: Distant supermassive black holes spotted in galaxy merger
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-00950-0

Observations from five telescopes have revealed a pair of supermassive black holes in coalescing galaxies, farther from Earth than any such pair detected previously. This feat offers key insight into how galaxies form.
item.dc:title: Distant supermassive black holes spotted in galaxy merger
item.dc:creator: Cristiana Spingola

item.title: When influenza viruses don’t play well with others
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-00983-5

Influenza viruses that infect the same host can interfere with each other’s replication. This behaviour seems to result in spatial structuring of infected groups of cells in tissue, with implications for viral evolution.
item.dc:title: When influenza viruses don’t play well with others
item.dc:creator: Mireille Farjo
Christopher B. Brooke

item.title: Diversity in German science: researchers push for missing ethnicity data
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-00955-9

The European country is one of several reassessing its cultural unease with collecting information on scientists’ race and ethnicity.
item.dc:title: Diversity in German science: researchers push for missing ethnicity data
item.dc:creator: Hristio Boytchev

item.title: COVID-origins data from Wuhan market published: what scientists think
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-00998-y

First peer-reviewed analysis of the Chinese swabs confirms animal DNA was present in samples that tested positive for SARS-CoV-2.
item.dc:title: COVID-origins data from Wuhan market published: what scientists think
item.dc:creator: Dyani Lewis
Max Kozlov
Mariana Lenharo

item.title: Mechanism of messenger-RNA decoding in humans illuminated
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-00727-5

Intracellular machines called ribosomes use messenger-RNA sequences to synthesize proteins. Investigations using single-molecule imaging and cryo-electron microscopy techniques reveal structural and kinetic differences in how human ribosomes function compared with those of bacteria. These differences explain why ribosomes in cell-nucleus-bearing species are slower and more accurate than their bacterial counterparts.
item.dc:title: Mechanism of messenger-RNA decoding in humans illuminated

item.title: Medieval accounts of eclipses shine light on massive volcanic eruptions
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-00939-9

Descriptions of lunar eclipses by monks and other scholars help scientists to pinpoint effects of ancient eruptions.
item.dc:title: Medieval accounts of eclipses shine light on massive volcanic eruptions
item.dc:creator: Jeff Tollefson

item.title: Tourist season
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-00958-6

Culture clash.
item.dc:title: Tourist season
item.dc:creator: Marissa Lingen

item.title: How air pollution causes lung cancer — without harming DNA
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-00989-z

Studies in mice suggest that tumour growth is triggered by inflammation caused by tiny particles, rather than genetic mutations.
item.dc:title: How air pollution causes lung cancer — without harming DNA
item.dc:creator: Heidi Ledford

item.title: How rapidly can ice sheets retreat?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-00916-2

Landforms across the mid-Norwegian sea floor reveal that a former ice sheet retreated at up to 600 metres per day at the end of the last ice age. Pulses of similarly rapid retreat could soon be observed across flat-bedded areas of the Antarctic Ice Sheet.
item.dc:title: How rapidly can ice sheets retreat?

item.title: Greenhouse-gas effects of land-use change in Indonesian peatlands
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-00944-y

Land-use changes alter the exchange of greenhouse gases, but the magnitudes of these effects remain uncertain. Estimates of net greenhouse-gas emissions associated with different uses of tropical peatland in Indonesia — including intact forest and Acacia tree plantations — could inform science-based practices for managing peatlands as nature-based mitigators of climate change.
item.dc:title: Greenhouse-gas effects of land-use change in Indonesian peatlands

item.title: The medieval Moon unveils volcanic secrets
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-00850-3

Innovative use of medieval musings about the Moon has revealed that volcanic eruptions coincided with abrupt, global-scale cooling events. The approach is exciting from the perspective of climate scientists and historians alike.
item.dc:title: The medieval Moon unveils volcanic secrets
item.dc:creator: Andrea Seim
Eduardo Zorita
Anne Lawrence-Mathers

item.title: Enzyme-inspired catalyst helps to convert methane into methanol
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-00810-x

A catalyst with a hydrophobic cavity that contains an active iron centre has been developed to convert methane into methanol. It has a ‘catch-and-release’ mechanism whereby a hydrophobic methane molecule enters the cavity for oxidation and the resulting hydrophilic methanol molecule is released into the surrounding aqueous solution.
item.dc:title: Enzyme-inspired catalyst helps to convert methane into methanol

item.title: General Access to Cubanes as Benzene Bioisosteres
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 04 April 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06021-8

General Access to Cubanes as Benzene Bioisosteres
item.dc:title: General Access to Cubanes as Benzene Bioisosteres

item.title: From the archive: the wonders of life contained in the soil, and the sociability of cats
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 04 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-00849-w

Snippets from Nature’s past.
item.dc:title: From the archive: the wonders of life contained in the soil, and the sociability of cats

item.title: World’s biggest butterfly is low on genetic diversity
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 04 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-00908-2

An endangered butterfly, found only in Papua New Guinea, has had a small population for a million years.
item.dc:title: World’s biggest butterfly is low on genetic diversity

item.title: Habit-linked brain circuits light up in people with eating disorders
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 04 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-00967-5

Parts of the brain associated with habit formation seem unusually active in people with eating disorders.
item.dc:title: Habit-linked brain circuits light up in people with eating disorders
item.dc:creator: Bianca Nogrady

item.title: Himalayan glaciers are losing weight faster than thought
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 04 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-00910-8

Sensor-laden research vessels help to measure how much ice is being lost under lake surfaces.
item.dc:title: Himalayan glaciers are losing weight faster than thought

item.title: Dear scientists: stop calling America the ‘New World’
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 04 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-00992-4

It’s new to you — but not to me or anyone else who grew up here, writes Fernanda Adame.
item.dc:title: Dear scientists: stop calling America the ‘New World’
item.dc:creator: Fernanda Adame

item.title: How virtual models of the brain could transform epilepsy surgery
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 04 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-00990-6

An ongoing clinical trial aims to test whether digital models built using brain-scan data can help to identify where seizures originate.
item.dc:title: How virtual models of the brain could transform epilepsy surgery
item.dc:creator: Miryam Naddaf

item.title: Carbon dioxide removal is not a current climate solution — we need to change the narrative
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 04 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-00953-x

Drastically reduce emissions first, or carbon dioxide removal will be next to useless.
item.dc:title: Carbon dioxide removal is not a current climate solution — we need to change the narrative
item.dc:creator: David T. Ho

item.title: Daily briefing: The billion-dollar plan to return rocks from Mars
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 04 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01001-4

Samples collected by the Perseverance rover await a challenging retrieval. Plus, a worrying rise in banned ozone-killing chemicals and how light waves squeezed through ‘slits in time’.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: The billion-dollar plan to return rocks from Mars
item.dc:creator: Flora Graham

item.title: European backsliding on electric vehicles is bad news for the climate
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 04 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-00951-z

Attempts to put a brake on the transition to electrification and allow ‘climate neutral’ fuels after 2035 ignore the science — what’s needed is policy clarity now.
item.dc:title: European backsliding on electric vehicles is bad news for the climate

item.title: Conquering Alzheimer’s: a look at the therapies of the future
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 04 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-00954-w

Researchers are looking to drug combinations, vaccines and gene therapy as they forge the next generation of treatments for the condition.
item.dc:title: Conquering Alzheimer’s: a look at the therapies of the future
item.dc:creator: Alison Abbott

item.title: SARS-CoV-2 Omicron boosting induces de novo B cell response in humans
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 April 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06025-4

SARS-CoV-2 Omicron boosting induces de novo B cell response in humans
item.dc:title: SARS-CoV-2 Omicron boosting induces de novo B cell response in humans

item.title: Cultivating cannabis in the shadow of a volcano
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-00957-7

Agriculturist Rohan McDonald is rebuilding a medical-cannabis laboratory after an eruption destroyed his team’s work.
item.dc:title: Cultivating cannabis in the shadow of a volcano
item.dc:creator: James Mitchell Crow

item.title: High-precision genomic tool tackles deadly mutation
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-00906-4

Genome editing raises levels of a protein that is scarce in people with spinal muscular atrophy.
item.dc:title: High-precision genomic tool tackles deadly mutation

item.title: Hello, baby: genes involved in timing of birth are identified
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-00909-1

Some genes that influence the length of a pregnancy also hold sway over fetal growth rates.
item.dc:title: Hello, baby: genes involved in timing of birth are identified
